items.title: Times containing decimals not understood intuitively
items.body:
Using decimals as in `0.5 minutes` or `1.5 hours` are not understood 'correctly' (intuitively) by dateparser.

Reproducing:
1. clone repo as of now
2. create fresh venv
3. pip install .
4:
    import dateparser
    dateparser.parse('now') - dateparser.parse('0.5 minutes')

I would expect this to produce 30 seconds but instead it produces 5 minutes (300 seconds). Whilst decimals are not particularly common, it might be desireable to clear up this behaviour to behave slightly more intuitively.

This could also be an artifact of another real language that prefers to use periods rather than colons to delimit times (if anyone can confirm?)

Python version: 3.8.2 GCC 9.3.0 on Linux
Dateparser: from master
Regex: 2.5.83
Pytz: 2020.1
Six: 1.15.0

items.title: Dateparser parses NaN to date one month from current date
items.body:
dateparser version: 0.7.6

Issue occurred when parsing a column in a pandas dataframe through dateparser.

Blanks in the dataframe which are interpreted as NaN, when cast to a string and parsed through dateparser would return a date one month from today.

Reproduction:

```
import dateparser
import math
print(dateparser.parse(str(math.nan)))
```

Example output: 
2020-08-20 00:00:00

milestone.title: v1.0.0
milestone.description:
We are preparing a new major version: `dateparser==1.0.0`.

These are the expected changes included in this version:

Breaking changes:
* Remove Python 2.7 support
* Check settings (https://github.com/scrapinghub/dateparser/pull/630)
* New timezones default values (https://github.com/scrapinghub/dateparser/issues/683)

Other new features:

* Support natural language written numbers (https://github.com/scrapinghub/dateparser/pull/711)
* Hiriji Calendar with support for Python 3 (https://github.com/scrapinghub/dateparser/pull/718)

Bugs fixes (https://github.com/scrapinghub/dateparser/pull/715, https://github.com/scrapinghub/dateparser/issues/643, etc) and docs improvements.

items.title: Latest release creates namespace conflict for scripts directory
items.body:
it looks like the dateparser pip package creates a namespace conflict for scripts directory.
So any project containing a scripts module in its root directory will no longer be able to use it.

**Example Project Directory:**
- env/
- scripts/
     - foo/
          - bar.py

if you install dateparser `pip install dateparser` and you run your script: `python -m scripts.foo.bar`

**you get error:**
`Error while finding module specification for 'scripts.foo.bar' (ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'scripts.foo')`

but when you uninstall dateparser `pip uninstall dateparser`

**No namespace confict:**
`python -m scripts.foo.bar`
`foo bar`

items.title: Bad handling of big numbers (OverflowError)
items.body:
There are a lot of situations where using a big number we get an `OverflowError`:

```python3
>>> dateparser.parse('123456789 hour')
OverflowError: date value out of range

>>> dateparser.parse('123456789123 hour')
OverflowError: Python int too large to convert to C int

>>> dateparser.parse('1234567 days') 
OverflowError: date value out of range

>>> dateparser.parse('1234567891 days') 
OverflowError: days=-1234567891; must have magnitude <= 999999999

>>> dateparser.parse('12345678912 days') 
OverflowError: Python int too large to convert to C int

>>> dateparser.parse('123455678976543 month')
OverflowError: signed integer is less than minimum
```
It happens the same for `week`, `year`, etc.

This case, handled by python3.6 calendar seems better:
```python
>>> dateparser.parse('123456789 year') 
ValueError: year -123454769 is out of range
```

However, I think we should just ignore or return `None` if any of these cases is found.

items.title: dateparser.parse raises unexpected errors in some edge cases
items.body:
I ran the `dateparser.parse` method against all the strings included in the [Big List of Naughty Strings](https://github.com/minimaxir/big-list-of-naughty-strings/blob/master/blns.json) and I found 4 edge cases where `dateparser` raises an error.

**Big number string:**

```python3
dateparser.parse('2.2250738585072011e-308') 
OverflowError: Python int too large to convert to C int
```

**Subscript or superscript numbers:**

```python3
dateparser.parse('⁰⁴⁵')
ValueError: invalid literal for int() with base 10: '⁰⁴⁵'
```

```python3
dateparser.parse('₀₁₂')
ValueError: invalid literal for int() with base 10: '₀₁₂'
```

```python3
dateparser.parse('⁰⁴⁵₀₁₂') 
ValueError: invalid literal for int() with base 10: '⁰⁴⁵₀₁₂'
```

I know these are edge cases, but it should be fixed as this package can be used to parse user inputs and it could be a security flaw.

Note that `search_dates()` seems not to be affected.

P.S: I'm happy to see that a lot of strings would have failed before merging this: https://github.com/scrapinghub/dateparser/pull/622 and now they work as expected.

items.title: Time does not work if timezone is provided
Dateparser: Memory Leak
items.body:
Hi! 

I've been working with dateparser in a web service application and recently have been seeing a memory leak where RAM consumption has continually increased as the service processes inbound requests. After doing some digging around, tracemalloc shows the following:

```
dateparser/languages/dictionary.py:213: size=260 MiB (+260 MiB), count=4491080 (+4491080), average=61 B
dateparser/languages/dictionary.py:184: size=129 MiB (+129 MiB), count=112281 (+112281), average=1207 B
dateparser/languages/locale.py:385: size=79.8 MiB (+79.8 MiB), count=699384 (+699384), average=120 B
dateparser/conf.py:50: size=61.7 MiB (+61.7 MiB), count=112276 (+112276), average=576 B
dateparser/languages/dictionary.py:214: size=48.7 MiB (+48.7 MiB), count=112280 (+112280), average=455 B
dateparser/languages/locale.py:380: size=14.8 MiB (+14.8 MiB), count=215570 (+215570), average=72 B
```

Looking at the source code, I see these five dictionaries defined in dictionary.py:
```
    _split_regex_cache = {}
    _sorted_words_cache = {}
    _split_relative_regex_cache = {}
    _sorted_relative_strings_cache = {}
    _match_relative_regex_cache = {}
```

Would there be a way for the caller to invalidate or disable this caching mechanism?

items.title: Portuguese month/day ordering bug
items.body:
There is a bug with Portuguese dates where dateparser switches the month and day ordering. This regression occurred sometime between v0.6.0 and v0.7.0.

Example text is "segunda 10-02-2015 4:06am", which should parse to "2015-02-10" but currently parses to "2015-10-02".

I've created PR #438 to add a unit test that exposes this regression: https://github.com/scrapinghub/dateparser/pull/438/files#diff-36128d81467a740315c9e5f49860c291

Based on my git-bisect testing, it looks like 8c24e3a is the first commit to break this. Or, at least, the first commit where import dateparser works successfully and the test is broken.

items.body:
yielded from this issue: https://github.com/scrapinghub/dateparser/issues/568#issuecomment-533514990 by @lopuhin 

```
In [151]: dateparser.parse('of a')
Out[151]: datetime.datetime(2019, 1, 20, 0, 0)

In [152]: dateparser.parse('of an')
Out[152]: datetime.datetime(2019, 1, 20, 0, 0)

Out[153]: datetime.datetime(2019, 1, 20, 0, 0)

In [154]: dateparser.parse('a')
Out[154]: datetime.datetime(2019, 1, 20, 0, 0)

In [159]: dateparser.parse('a', settings={'STRICT_PARSING': True}, languages=['en'])
Out[159]: datetime.datetime(1900, 1, 1, 1, 0)

In [160]: dateparser.parse('an', settings={'STRICT_PARSING': True}, languages=['en'])
Out[160]: datetime.datetime(1900, 1, 1, 1, 0)

```

We should investigate why these strings are parsed as valid dates and fix them to return `None` (if they are not valid).

DateParser Documentation, Release 0.7.2
3.3 OOTB Language Based Date Order Preference
>>> # parsing ambiguous date
>>> parse('02-03-2016') # assumes english language, uses MDY date order
datetime.datetime(2016, 3, 2, 0, 0)

items.title: Unable to parse UTC / GMT >= 10
items.body:
Noticing a bug where GMT-10 is not parsing, but GMT-5 is:

```
>>> dateparser.parse("Thu Feb 06 2020, 04:00:00 GMT-5")
datetime.datetime(2020, 2, 6, 4, 0, tzinfo=<StaticTzInfo 'UTC\-05:00'>)
>>> dateparser.parse("Thu Feb 06 2020, 04:00:00 GMT-10")
>>>
```

It appears that double-digit parsing isn't supported:

```
>>> dateparser.parse("Thu Feb 06 2020, 04:00:00 GMT-9")
datetime.datetime(2020, 2, 6, 4, 0, tzinfo=<StaticTzInfo 'UTC\-09:00'>)
>>> dateparser.parse("Thu Feb 06 2020, 04:00:00 GMT-11")
>>> dateparser.parse("Thu Feb 06 2020, 04:00:00 GMT-12")
>>> dateparser.parse("Thu Feb 06 2020, 04:00:00 GMT-12")
```

If it's converted to UTC-10:00 it does parse:
```
>>> dateparser.parse("Thu Feb 06 2020, 04:00:00 UTC-10:00")
datetime.datetime(2020, 2, 6, 4, 0, tzinfo=<StaticTzInfo 'UTC\-10:00'>)
```

items.title: `SUPPORT_BEFORE_COMMON_ERA` declared but not working
items.body:
I was curious about this setting and I found only two references: https://github.com/scrapinghub/dateparser/search?q=SUPPORT_BEFORE_COMMON_ERA

It seems that this setting was added here: https://github.com/scrapinghub/dateparser/commit/02d525107abcfe720b6495df8d8a1eb9028d7930 as an example/proposal (https://github.com/scrapinghub/dateparser/issues/35) but it has never been implemented.

I think we should remove it from the codebase to avoid confusions and add it again when developing it.

items.title: Fix dependencies version
items.body:
Hi there,
today my CI pipeline failed to build my docker image in which the python code references your lib.
It failed because gcc was missing from my image which was not the case the last time it was built (4 days ago).
After some investigation why the gcc was required, I found that regex was the culprit. regex is a dependency of dateparser and it was updated yesterday with the version 2019.12.9.

It is a good pratice to fix the version of all dependencies when you release a version of a lib because without changing the version of a lib, it might crash because a dependency has changed.

thanks for your job on this lib :)

items.title: dateparser.parse returns None for any datetime using 24hr format and time period when hour is > 12
items.body:
Whils't parsing some data I got an error when processing `Sep 28, 2016, 20:13 pm`, I believe this is due to a conflict between 24 hour time format and a time period being supplied.
```
>>> print(dateparser.parse('Sep 28, 2016, 12:13 PM'))
2016-09-28 12:13:00
>>> print(dateparser.parse('Sep 28, 2016, 11:13 PM'))
2016-09-28 23:13:00
>>> print(dateparser.parse('Sep 28, 2016, 13:13 PM'))
None
>>> print(dateparser.parse('Sep 28, 2016, 13:13 AM'))
None
>>> 
```
I know this isn't technically valid since the period is not needed with 24hr format. Instead of returning `None` I believe that it would be useful to instead just ignore the given period and fallback on the given 24hr format.

i.e.:
`Sep 28, 2016, 13:13 AM` -> `Sep 28, 2016, 13:13`
`Sep 28, 2016, 13:13 PM` -> `Sep 28, 2016, 13:13`

```
{'date_obj': datetime.datetime(2018, 1, 10, 0, 0), 'period': 'day', 'locale': 'de'}

{'date_obj': datetime.datetime(2018, 10, 1, 0, 0), 'period': 'day', 'locale': 'de'}  # inverted date / month

{'date_obj': datetime.datetime(2018, 1, 10, 0, 0), 'period': 'day', 'locale': 'de'}  # correct
```

items.title: No option for PREFER_DATES_FROM for current day
items.body:
It would be nice if there was an additional option to prefer the current date if available over the future or past one when parsing relative dates. This is primarily an issue when parsing dates in news articles, where the current date will be referred to only by the day of the week. 

For example, an article written on Friday, March 8 will use only the word "Friday" to describe March 8. But parsing 'Friday' with `'PREFER_DATES_FROM': 'future'` will return Friday, March 15 and  `'PREFER_DATES_FROM': 'past'` will return March 1.

Here's how I could imagine it working:

```python
>>> dateparser.parse('Friday', settings={
  'RELATIVE_BASE': datetime.datetime(2019, 3, 8),
  'PREFER_DATES_FROM':  'future',
  'PREFER_CURRENT_DATE': True
})
# Since RELATIVE_BASE is a Friday, returns RELATIVE_BASE
datetime.datetime(2019, 3, 8)
```

```python
>>> dateparser.parse('Friday', settings={
  'RELATIVE_BASE': datetime.datetime(2019, 3, 8),
  'PREFER_DATES_FROM':  'future',
  'PREFER_CURRENT_DATE': False
})

datetime.datetime(2019, 3, 15)
```

I can try to find some time to implement this if other people would find it useful.

Just making you aware and hoping that we get a real fix for this soon. Thanks

items.title: Parsing relative date with timezone returns wrong datetime
items.body:
Ubuntu 18.10, Python 3.7, dateparser 0.7.0

```
>>> datetime.now().strftime('%Y-%m-%d %H:%M')  # I'm in CET
'2019-02-06 18:42'
>>> dateparser.parse('tomorrow 08:30 CST').strftime('%Y-%m-%d %H:%M %Z')
'2019-02-07 11:42 CST'
```
Two things are wrong IMO:
- the time (08:30) is ignored
- the timezone is converted (to CST)

The expected outcome would be: `'2019-02-07 08:30 CST'`. With absolute dates or without timezone, everything works as expected:
```

'2019-02-07 08:30 CST'
>>> dateparser.parse('tomorrow 08:30').strftime('%Y-%m-%d %H:%M')
'2019-02-07 08:30'
```

Using current master (289fcc4ca936069b2c75bb5378b4136633b3edf9) we see quadratic complexity with respect to the number of date-like numbers in the input:

```
%time _ = search_dates(' '.join(str(2000 + i) for i in range(20)))

Wall time: 3.4 s
```

Timings with `` languages=['en'])`` are the same.

https://github.com/scrapinghub/dateparser/issues/439 might be related

items.title: Please make a new release
items.body:
Hello up there. First of all I'd like to say thanks for dateparser.

We are using it in [zodbtools](https://lab.nexedi.com/nexedi/zodbtools/merge_requests/8) to parse human-readable times into transaction ID. We found however that the parsing is very slow if the date/time input is invalid and cannot be parsed into a timestamp. This issue was already [reported](https://github.com/scrapinghub/dateparser/issues/426) and somewhat [fixed](https://github.com/scrapinghub/dateparser/pull/428) in 2018. However there is no dateparser version released with the fix.

Since last version of dateparser - v0.7.0 - was released in Feb of 2018 - approximately 1 year ago, it suggests that another release is due by.

So could you please release the next version of dateparser and upload it to PyPI?

Thanks beforehand,
Kirill

/cc @perrinjerome

items.title: requirements.txt out of date
items.body:
since #265, the `requirements.txt` file is "pinned" to older versions of dependencies. in some cases they go back to three year old (2016) dependencies. for normal operation, that isn't much of a problem, but it makes the test suite run with an outdated set of packages, which do not reflect real world operation.

in particular, while trying to build a Debian package for this module, I have struggled to make the test suite pass because the modules packaged in Debian are newer than the dependencies specified in `requirements.txt`. at least I *think* that's the reason the test suite is failing in my environment and not travis.

it would be nice to update those dependencies to more recent versions. for example pytz has a 2018 release, but this affects basically other dependencies as well.

thank you for your consideration and for the extensive test suite. :)

items.title: search_dates neglects timezone information
items.body:
It looks quite strange to me that while `parse()` manages to parse timezone information and returns timezone-aware datetime object by default:
```
>>> from dateparser import parse
>>> parse('January 12, 2012 10:00 PM EST')
datetime.datetime(2012, 1, 12, 22, 0, tzinfo=<StaticTzInfo 'EST'>)
>>> parse("Aug 06, 2018 05:05 PM CDT")
datetime.datetime(2018, 8, 6, 17, 5, tzinfo=<StaticTzInfo 'CDT'>)
```
The same does not apply to `dateparser.search.search_dates()`:
```
>>> from dateparser.search import search_dates
>>> search_dates("Aug 06, 2018 05:05 PM CDT")
[('Aug 06, 2018 05:05 PM', datetime.datetime(2018, 8, 6, 17, 5))]
```

items.title: Wish list: please add a feature to set the country for the datetime being parsed.  This is much more useful than language or region for narrowing down which timezone is being referred to.
items.body:
Wish list: please add a feature to set the country for the datetime being parsed.  This is much more useful than language or region for narrowing down which timezone is being referred to.

Language is helpful generally for months and alphanumeric numbers, articles, etc.. but not helpful in analyzing the timezone or timezone rules of the parsed text.  Locale is more about parsing rules and may have very little to do with the location for the datetime.  In other words if I am in France and using a datetime for my child's birthplace birthplace which is not France, then the timezone abbreviation will be ambiguous
s.  Sure I can use the long timezone code, but users generally won't know those, and sources may not be friendly to that.  Since the parser handles tz abbreviations there needs to be a way to remove or reduce ambiguity.
someone opened an issue form my github.

items.title: 'locales' and 'languages' ignored when RELATIVE_BASE is set
items.body:
Case in point:

```python
from datetime import datetime
import dateparser

# This one parses the date as a US locale date, i.e. October 9th
dateparser.parse('9-10-2010', settings={'RELATIVE_BASE':datetime(2011,10,10)})
Out[1]: datetime.datetime(2010, 9, 10, 0, 0)

# This one parses the same date as IT locale, i.e. September 10th
dateparser.parse('9-10-2010', locales=['it'])
Out[3]: datetime.datetime(2010, 10, 9, 0, 0)

# But if I set the RELATIVE_BASE again, the locale information is discarded.
dateparser.parse('9-10-2010', settings={'RELATIVE_BASE':datetime(2011,10,10)}, locales=['it'])
Out[2]: datetime.datetime(2010, 9, 10, 0, 0)
```

This behavior is a problem for me because I have to parse a date field that can be a relative or absolute date in a foreign language (Russian), so I need to keep RELATIVE_BASE always set in case I stumble upon a relative date, but at the same time it has to respect the Russian locale DD-MM-YYYY.

I also tried setting the `languages`parameter instead of `locales`, as well as both. No change.

Thank  you.

items.title: Huge performance problem: `DateDataParser` stored multiple duplicate `previous_locales`
items.body:
We got surprised that `dateparser.parse()` gets slower over time (in a long-running process ~1 day), from hundereds of ms to 3 seconds per call! One possible cause is the following:

`DateDataParser.get_date_data()` stores some previously used locales:

```
if self.try_previous_locales:
    self.previous_locales.insert(0, locale)
```

However, we observed that `dateparser._default_parser.previous_locales` contained many duplicate instances of the same set of locales. Eg. 2189 instances of 63 unique locales.

The problem with the code above is that `self.previous_locales` should be a set, possibly ordered, but there's no check that `locale` is already inside.

Anyway, even when we run `dateparser.parse()` it's pretty slow (~400 ms / item). However with only `languages=['en]` it's really fast (~0.25 ms / item).

Package version: latest 0.7.0, Python 2.7.

items.title: (some?) settings not being applied with custom date_formats
items.body:
- version: 0.7.0

I have the following case:

This is the expected behaviour of the setting `'PREFER_DAY_OF_MONTH'` without using personalized `date_formats`:
```python3
dateparser.parse('august 2016')
# >> datetime.datetime(2016, 8, 19, 0, 0)
dateparser.parse('august 2016', settings={'PREFER_DAY_OF_MONTH': 'first')
# >> datetime.datetime(2016, 8, 1, 0, 0)
```
Now let's say we want to parse "august-16" as "august of 2016", so we use the custom format `"%B-%y"`. We obtain the right behaviour:
```python3
dateparser.parse('august-16', date_formats=['%B-%y'])
# >> datetime.datetime(2016, 8, 31, 0, 0)
```
And now let's use the setting `'PREFER_DAY_OF_MONTH'` along with the `date_formats`:
```python3
dateparser.parse('august-16', date_formats=['%B-%y'], settings={'PREFER_DAY_OF_MONTH': 'first'})
# >> datetime.datetime(2016, 8, 31, 0, 0)
```

In this case, `dateparser.parser` has ignored the settings and returned the last day of month instead of the first one.`.

items.title: Doesn't support official Finnish H.MM hour/minute separator
items.body:
In Finnish, the official separator between hours and minutes is a period instead of a colon (see [instructions](http://www.kielitoimistonohjepankki.fi/haku/kellonajat/ohje/51) from the Institute for the Languages of Finland).

However, dateparser fails to parse such time formats:
```bash
$ pip install git+https://github.com/scrapinghub/dateparser.git
Collecting git+https://github.com/scrapinghub/dateparser.git
  Cloning https://github.com/scrapinghub/dateparser.git to /tmp/pip-req-build-0kyg7s0s

Collecting six>=1.5 (from python-dateutil->dateparser==0.7.0)
Building wheels for collected packages: dateparser
  Running setup.py bdist_wheel for dateparser ... done
  Stored in directory: /tmp/pip-ephem-wheel-cache-dki7rjsx/wheels/9d/f4/3f/38fc18e2a9913cbd29fb915b9088d75d34816794b5e0faf063
Successfully built dateparser
Installing collected packages: six, python-dateutil, pytz, regex, tzlocal, dateparser
Successfully installed dateparser-0.7.0 python-dateutil-2.7.3 pytz-2018.4 regex-2018.6.6 six-1.11.0 tzlocal-1.5.1
$ python
Python 3.6.5 (default, Apr  4 2018, 15:09:05) 
[GCC 7.3.1 20180130 (Red Hat 7.3.1-2)] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
```

```python
>>> import dateparser
>>> dateparser.parse('5.7.2018 5.45 ip.')  # period
>>> dateparser.parse('5.7.2018 5:45 ip.')  # colon
datetime.datetime(2018, 7, 5, 17, 45)
```

Operating system: Fedora 26
Python version: 3.6.5

items.title: Setting DATE_ORDER 'MDY' allows for parsing 'DMY', but not vice versa
items.body:
I process a wide range of different date formats, but most of them are in 'DMY' format, therefore I use the setting 'DATE_ORDER' = 'DMY'. However, when I try to parse the occasional 'MDY' format I get no result:

```
>>> dateparser.parse('01-13-2015', settings={'DATE_ORDER': 'DMY'})
None
```

However, if the (default) 'MDY' format is set, it allows for flexibility:

```
>>> dateparser.parse('13-01-2015', settings={'DATE_ORDER': 'MDY'})
datetime.datetime(2015, 1, 13, 0, 0)
```

Why doesn't the 'DMY' setting fall back on 'MDY' when necessary, but the 'MDY' does in fact fall back on 'DMY'?

items.title: Dates before "01/01/69" get parsed to 20** instead of 19**
items.body:
Not a bug per se, but I wanted to have a discussion around parsing dates where the millennium is not specified. It looks like any date of the format "DD/MM/YY" before "01/01/69" gets parsed to the next millennium. Is this intended behavior? Is there a reason that date specifically gets parsed to 1969 but anything before gets parsed to 20** ? this is python3.4, dateparser 0.7.0. thanks all! 

```
>>> value = "01/01/69"
>>> dateparser.parse(value)
datetime.datetime(1969, 1, 1, 0, 0)
>>> value = "12/31/68"
>>> dateparser.parse(value)
datetime.datetime(2068, 12, 31, 0, 0)
```

-> OK

```
date = 'mar, 20 set 2016 09:39:59 CET'
parse(date)
None
```

**-> KO**
Why this, while all shuld be valid?

import dateparser

print(dateparser.parse("Saturday May 26, 2018  00:22 AM", date_formats=['dddd MMM D, yyyy  hh:mm tt']))
**None**

print(dateparser.parse("Saturday May 26, 2018  01:22 AM", date_formats=['dddd MMM D, yyyy  hh:mm tt']))
**2018-05-26 01:22:00**

The first call takes a second to return and only returns None and not an object.

**dateparser==0.7.0**

Greetings 
Ansi

items.title: Parsing '2018-04-12 17:20:03.12345678999a' raises an exception
items.body:
To reproduce:
```
import dateparser
dateparser.parse('2018-04-12 17:20:03.12345678999a')
```

On Windows, CPython 3.6.4, and dateparser 0.7.0, this raises OverflowError (Python int too large to convert to C long).
On Linux, CPython 3.6.4, and dateparser 0.7.0, this raises OverflowError (signed integer is less than minimum).
On Linux, Pypy 5.10.1, and dateparser 0.7.0, this raises ValueError ('year must be in 1..9999', -12345676981).

I expected parsing to fail and return None, or, in the future, raise, e.g.,  DateParserError.

```dateparser.parse('2018-04-12 17:20:03.12345678999b')``` succeeds in all above platforms.
